Question: Consider the following data in (coordinate, sign) format: ((-4, 4),positive), ((4, -4),positive), ((-1, -1),-1) , ((1, 1),-1). Clearly, the points are not linearly separable, so we will try three alternative approaches to solving the problem. Suppose $K\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)=e^{-\left\|x-x^{\prime}\right\|^{2}}$ and for the points in our data set, $K\left(p_{i}, p_{j}\right)=\mathbf{K}_{i j}$ where the matrix $$ \mathbf{K} \approx\left[\begin{array}{cccc} 1 & \exp (-15) & \exp (-15) & \exp (-56) \\ \exp (-15) & 1 & \exp (-4) & \exp (-15) \\ \exp (-15) & \exp (-4) & 1 & \exp (-15) \\ \exp (-56) & \exp (-15) & \exp (-15) & 1 \end{array}\right] $$ (b) Now we will use the kernel perceptron algorithm to find the $\alpha$ values in the classifer, which has the form $$ y_{\text {predicted }}=\operatorname{sign}\left(\sum_{i=1}^{4} \alpha_{i} y^{(i)} K\left(x^{(i)}, x\right)\right) $$ Assuming that we go through the points in order $p 1, p 2, p 3, p 4$ as many times as necessary to correctly classify the data, what is the value of $\alpha_{3}?
